fields.descriptive_line: Hand coloured board game, Puzzles versus Puzzles, published in England by William Darton in about 1825
fields.physical_description:
Design: engraving, coloured by hand; mounted on linen;  designed in the shape of an eight pointed star with the title between 1 and 2 and the subtitle running between all the points
No. of squares: 39
Squares illustrated: corners only
Square numbering: all
Squares titled: none
Subject of starting square: riddle
Subject of ending square: riddle related to towns
fields.title: A ^New Game or Puzzles versus Puzzles
fields.public_access_description: This game is subtitled ‘seven puzzles designed for the entertainment of children in winter evenings etc’. It combines answering questions with movement around the board. There are no directions as such, but 39 puzzles for the players to work out. These take the form of riddles, anagrams and word puzzles for birds and English towns. Examples include: what we all do at every meal is a swallow, and a resting place and a wet walk is Bedford.
fields.history_note:
The game combines the answers of questions with movement around the board which has no given directions but a further puzzle for the players to work out.
Willaim Darton at the 58 Holborn Hill address, after 1819 and before 1830.
fields.historical_context_note:
Rewards: none
Forfeits: none
No. of Players: any
Equipment required: only the playing sheet

Rules:
The playing sheet shows 8 numbered compartments situated at each apex of an eight pointed star, within which are numbered conumdrums.  The solutions are to each side.
In the centre are further directions for the players which read:

In addition to solving the conumdrums, transpositions etc, the young player is expected to cover seven of the points marked 1, 2, 3, etc. by going along the different lines, but without passing over the same line twice.  The mode of doing this he is left to discover by the exercise of his own ingenuity.

There are 39 riddles, anagrams etc as follows:
1.   Why is a person with his eyes closed like a defective schoolmaster?
      Because he keeps his pupils in darkness.
2.   What is that which lives in the winter, dies in the summer and grows with its                                            
      roots upward?  An icicle.
3.   Why is an empty house like a room  full of married people?
      Because there is not a single person in it.
4.   Pray tell me ladies if you can, Who is that highly favour'd man,
      Who, though he's married many a wife, may still live single all his life?
      A Clergyman.
5.   Why is a fixed star like pen, ink and paper?
      Because it's stationery.
6.   Why is a fender like Westminster Abbey?
      Because it confines the ashes of a grate.
7.   What class of people do I name by saying I cannot improve?
      Mend-i-cant.

TRANSPOSITIONS:
8.   No more Stars?  Astronomers.
9.   To love rain?  Revolution.
10.  In magic tale?  Enigmatical.
11.  A comical trade?  Democratical.
12.  Yes milton?  Solemnity.
13.  A hot pen?  Phaeton.
14.  A nice pet?  Patience.
15.  The War?  Wreath.
16.  Made in pint pots?  Disappointment.
17.  Truly he'll see war?  Arthur Wellesley.
18.  The Law?  Wealth.
19.  I mean to read it?  Determination.

BIRDS:
20.  A child's plaything?  Kite.
21.  What we all do at every meal?  Swallow.
22.  A disorder incident to man and horse?  Thrush
23.  An almanack maker?  Partridge.
 24.  A celebrated English architect?  Wren.
25.  A tailor's implement?  Goose.
26.  A lever?  Crow.
27.  An instrument for raising weights?  Crane.
28.  A distant country?  Turkey.

ENGLISH TOWNS:
29.  What are you doing at this moment?  Reading.
30.  Contention, and what belongs to a lamp?  Warwick.
31.  A wet toast ordered to labour?  Worksop.
32.  Bid a recluse continued feeding?  Nuneaton.
33.  Merchandise?  Ware.
34.  The seat of bile and a piece of water?  Liverpool.
35.  A resting place and a wet walk?  Bedford.
36.  A large vessel and a considerable weight?  Shipton.
37.  Timber and the riches of a merchant?  Woodstock.
38.  A bit of land belonging to the popes' predecessor?  Petersfield.
39.  A place at an inn and a fisherman's tool?  Barnet.

Corner pictures show a girl on a rocking horse, a man with a reindeer, birds in a tree and a travelling man.

Rules placement: centre of the playing sheet
